title: 105_s2513
content:
The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 includes provisions for land transfers involving Rogue River National Forest and other public land in Oregon, protection of Oregon and California Railroad Grant land, and conveyance to Deschutes County, Oregon. The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 involves transferring approximately 2,058 acres of public domain land within Rogue River National Forest in Oregon to the Forest, under the administrative jurisdiction of the Secretary of Agriculture. The land will be managed in accordance with the Weeks Law and other applicable laws. The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 involves transferring 1,632 acres of Federal land from Rogue River National Forest to unreserved public domain status under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Interior. The land will be administered according to laws applicable to unreserved public domain land. The Oregon Public Land Transfer and Protection Act of 1998 transfers approximately 4,298 acres of land from Rogue River National Forest to revested Oregon and California Railroad grant land under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the land according to relevant laws and regulations. The revested Oregon and California Railroad grant land, approximately 960 acres within Rogue River National Forest, is transferred to the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Agriculture for management in accordance with relevant laws. Revenues from the land will be distributed as specified in applicable legislation. The boundaries of Rogue River National Forest are adjusted to include transferred land and exclude private property interests. Maps depicting the boundary adjustments must be available for public inspection within 60 days. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture are required to revise public land records promptly after enactment of the Act. The section requires the revision of public land records to reflect changes in administrative jurisdiction and the publication of notice in the Federal Register regarding the land transfer. TITLE II--PROTECTION OF OREGON AND CALIFORNIA RAILROAD GRANT LAND: Defines terms related to the protection of the railroad grant land. The title defines terms related to the protection of O & C land, CBWR land, and public domain land. The title defines terms related to the protection of O & C land, CBWR land, and public domain land. The term "public lands" is defined as specified in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The term "geographic area" refers to specific districts in Oregon under the Bureau of Land Management. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 202. NO NET LOSS OF O & C LAND, CBWR LAND, OR PUBLIC DOMAIN LAND.

The Secretary must ensure that the number of acres of O & C land, CBWR land, and public domain land available for timber harvesting in a specific geographic area does not decrease over time.

SEC. 203. RELATIONSHIP TO UMPQUA LAND EXCHANGE AUTHORITY.

This title does not apply to land exchanges authorized under a specific act if consistent with a memorandum of understanding between the Umpqua Land Exchange Project and the Association of Oregon and California Land Grant Counties. TITLE III--CONVEYANCE TO DESCHUTES COUNTY, OREGON

SEC. 301. CONVEYANCE TO DESCHUTES COUNTY, OREGON. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to sell land to Deschutes County, Oregon at fair market value for clean water protection and social service delivery. This includes providing land for residential development, acquisition by nonprofit and governmental entities, and offering community amenities and services at little to no cost. The Secretary of the Interior may sell approximately 544 acres of land in Deschutes County, Oregon to assist in the implementation of the Deschutes County Regional Problem Solving Project. The land can be sold at fair market value and is described in detail in the section. The Secretary of the Interior may sell land in Deschutes County, Oregon, including specific government lots and portions, if deemed suitable for sale. Proceeds from the sale will be deposited in a special account for the purchase of environmentally sensitive land. The Secretary of the Interior may sell land in Deschutes County, Oregon for the purchase of environmentally sensitive land in Range Nine East. The Senate passed the legislation on October 9, 1998.
